title: How can a teenager get started in the music industry? - Quora

response.answer_text: 1.) First off, know what you’re signing up for. Being a music artist is not a job where you can sleep until noon, jam out for an hour, then get drunk or high at a party before your break. And even if/when you break through, getting too carried away with the party life has led multiple artists to their career’s ruin or even death. This is a low barrier, high competition job, which means a lot of people want the same thing as you, and many of them will match you in skill and/or work ethic, or even exceed it, and even if you get in, that doesn’t mean someone can’t outshine you and have you out of the media’s eye. Of course, you still gotta make school, family, and friends a priority first. But you also gotta be willing to bring your A game every day for probably years. 2.) Consider what genre you wanna do. Do you wanna be a pop singer constantly played on the Top 40 station? Do you wanna sing country and try to be this generation’s Dolly Parton? Do you wanna be a rock musician? Note that though there is an audience for all genres, you’re more likely to get commercial success in the pop, country, or R&B genre, as those are what dominate the current music industry right now. You might wanna do more than 1 genre, and that’s OK. However, keep in mind that nowadays music genres are lot more political. For example, when Taylor Swift was just starting to stray from country and country-pop with songs like “22”, “We are Never Ever Ever Getting Back Together”, and “I Knew You Were Trouble”, fans were already complaining that the “old” Taylor is gone (she definitely is now), even though in that same time she was still releasing Americana-esque, whimsy, feminine songs like “Start Again” and “Safe and Sound”. If you wanna be commercially successful, best stick to 2 related genres tops and not be overly eclectic early on. 3.) learn to write music. This isn’t really a requirement per se, especially when the pop music industry is loaded with singers who sing songs written by others. However, in a world where many people can sing or play an instrument well, knowing how to sing/play and bring your own stuff to the table makes you stand out more than the guy who sings covers of the most famous ’70s rock hits. Also, keep in mind that you don’t really need to have a high understanding of music theory for songwriting in most genres, but it will help a lot. Not just in writing down how your mudic goes, but to analyze the structures of other songs as well to see what goes on in what genre you wanna do. Ideally, with time, you’ll learn to write songs that are current but are also less formulaic than your competition. IMPORTANT: DO NOT SHARE ANY ORIGINAL MATERIAL WITHOUT COPYRIGHTING IT FIRST. Also, do not depend on “advice” to give evidence for copyright without copyrighting it, like emailing to yourself or signing and dating a sheet of paper with lyrics. In court, someone accused of infringing can only be convicted if your song is registered in the U.S. Copyright Office. U.S. Copyright Office 4.) PRACTICE. Pretty self-explanatory. Every day, for hours. You gotta keep pushing yourself 5.) Get your performances out there. YouTube is a good start. Go to open mic nights to learn how to get over stagefright, interact with the audience, and perform, not just sing/play. A great way for exposure (with downsides) is to go on a televised competition (X Factor, America/Britain’s Got Talent, etc.). The major flaw is that these are, first and foremost, TV shows. Before you even get a chance to perform on stage, you gotta audition with producers. They will determine if you make good TV material, talent aside. If you get through and are highly competent and become a top favorite contestant, however, it could easily give way to a big break. Also, try local events or venues. They might not pay, but it’s a great way to get exposure, especially if you do it regularly, and make connections. Once you establish a reputation and high enough skill, you can eventually move on to paid gigs. 6.) Connect with fans via social media. Have at least a Twitter and Instagram. A Facebook page is a big plus. Update them regularly. 7.) Be patient and persevere. Most people don’t become sensations within a year of committing to this path. Don’t assume you’ll be a lucky minority, even if you can play guitar like Hendrix or sing like Whitney Houston. Most likely, you will not become famous as a teen, but if this is a career you care about because you love to perform and not just in it for the fame and parties, you’ll learn to keep going even if you’re not always feeling the passion or drive, and be ultimately happier that you’re doing what you love than how many people know of you.

Starting in the industry itself can be as easy as picking up an instrument, recording a tune and releasing it yourself via cdbaby, Ditto Music, or the like. If you’re actually looking to get started in the music business without being an artist, that’s a bit different. Here are a few ways that can get Promote bands: I lucked out in growing up in Northern NJ where a confluence of events and people made for a rather thriving punk/ska scene that graduated touring bands like Midtown, Lanemeyer, Saves the Day, and Thursday among others. Now it’s easier than share your love/support for an artist with other people over social media. Offering to help an artist with their social media presence (an online street team) is one of the easier ways into working in music.Make / design merch: Often overlooked — If you’re hooked in with local artists and have some design/visual art inclination, you can always develop unique merch products and sell them at shows (or better yet, through sites like Merch by Amazon and Redbubble that will take care of upfront production expenses). Make sure to get the artists’ permission first (in writing). Even if you don’t know many local musicians, you can always link up with people on Reddit and offer to handle their merch in exchange for a royalty / financial compensation.Cover performances for a local or online newspaper: This is happening less and less. The ability to write and cover a live performance is one that can be done at any level/age (provided there’s no age-restriction at the venue).Book shows: This one’s a bit more challenging and will be contingent on organizational (and more importantly, trustworthiness) skills, but booking shows provides a great deal of access/exposure into the workings of the business.Volunteer for a local festival: Music festivals (and even non-music festivals that book live acts) are another way into the business. They’re more educational if you can link up with the talent booker, marketing personnel, or legal staff — all of whom will have some access to the broader industry.Make your own records: Easier said than done, but if you have music you’d love to see get introduced to a larger audience - there’s no finer introduction to the music business than trying to record and release a record with people you love.This is by no means exhaustive - hope it helps!

The most solid people in the “music industry" are those who just worked on the things they could do. Layla's answer is loaded with great advise. Since you're in the teens - unless you are sure of a music area you are magnetized to, you have time to grow and try different areas. Be careful of disposable trendy poppy things. If your a pure creative type then start writing your first 100 songs many of which will be for learning experience. A few may be keepers. You could get your own “sound" maybe your own act if you're obsessive enough, and yet personable enough to book gigs and bond with the audience. But you said “music industry". You might be a producer, recording engineer, a digital rights manager, a publisher, an owner of a record label. All “music industry” specialized areas that people cannot just fill out a job application get “hired". If your getting skilled in some way, the music industry will just find you in it somehow. Read that again. : )
